Just a note. The proprietor of Hubbard Avenue Diner reached out and addressed my issues. I really appreciate his attentiveness. That act alone will ensure that I try the diner again.

I was here with a group of people for a bruch/lunch on July 4. A busy morning, but we were lucky in that we only had to wait about 20 minutes for a table. Being a huge pie fan, I had a good time looking at the pies in the display cases.   For my meal, I had an omelet, with cheese and other stuff in it. It was good, but nothing too outstanding. I also had a slice of key lime pie. Delicious.   But the reason why I feel like I can't rate this place higher is due to the slow service. By the time we left, there were maybe 50% of the tables full. It had gotten the point in the day where the wait staff was wrapping silverware in napkins.   But I remember it took 15 minutes to get our pie. Literally, all they had to do is slice a few pieces of pie.   I would definitely go here again, but just expect for it to take longer to get served.

Best place in town for pie!  They have 10 standard flavored year round and about 5 seasonal flavors. You can help yourself to a seat at the bar and order from their full diner style menu or you can just enjoy a slice of pie. If you happen to come on pi (3/14) day, a nice line is formed to the left along the display pies and either get a slice or a whole pie to go ( $5 deposit for glass dish). The wait staff wear pi theme tshirt a which you can buy at the register.

Note: This review is ONLY for their bakery.  I ordered a cake for the boy's birthday, sight and taste unseen.  I have never been to Hubbard Avenue.  I was drawn in by their online order form that listed sizes, cake flavors, filling flavors, and frosting flavors.  There were just so many options!  And for $12.99!  Sold!  I called up and ordered a mocha cake with raspberry filling and mocha frosting.  The lady on the phone told me how good that sounded.  I know, Phone Lady, I know.  She asked for an inscription.  She then asked if I wanted any particular decoration.  Baffled, I said no, they could do whatever they wanted.  Upon hanging up, I hit myself in the forehead.  I should have specified that the cake was for a 31 year old man, not a 5 year old boy.  Shit.  Hopefully they don't put clowns or pokemon or something stupid on it.  I picked it up, and I was extremely pleased.  It was a pretty little cake, the color of wet sand, with a palm tree on it.  Tasteful (pun not intended)!  Professionalism and prettiness aside, it was a gloriously delicious cake.  The best part really is the mocha buttercream frosting.  I want that frosting on everything I eat from now on.  It'll be worth weighing 400 pounds.

good diner atmosphere, food was so so. had the ham and potatoe casserole and then a slice of caramel apple walnut pie ala mode. casserole was ok, not super flavorful. and honestly i wasn't amazed by the pie.

Went their recently at about 2:30pm.  Not very busy.   We had to wait a very long time for or orders to appear.   They were good.  I would rate my Rube about a 7 out of 10.   fair amount of corned beef.  good and flavorful cheese.   Sauce was so so.  Bread, ok but could have been better.   The Fiesta Chicken bowl was good with a nice variety of ingredients but we were sure it was to include poblano peppers which we couldn't find in the dish.   We should have said something but didn't. I requested soup with my sandwich for which I had to pay more for as a side.   It was just a cup of soup and not a bowl as I had hoped for.   Seemed skimpy to me.  The soup was good but nothing spectacular. The cheesecake was not that exciting.   It was ok.  Maybe a 6 out of 10.  I have gone back a few times since the above review in 2011.   The wait time has improved but the dinner meal is skimpy for the price and though the food is prepared fine the flavors are absent.   I have decided to not return for another dinner.   I might stop for breakfast if in a jam but will most likely go elsewhere.  Sorry but I have to scratch this restaurant off my list of places to go.

I am surprise this is not higher than 3.5 stars.  I have hit Hubbard mostly for breakfast and it has always been a very positive experience (if you don't mind a weekend morning wait).  Good service, good food, good variety, no weak points, which is rare these days.  I would go out of my way to eat at the Hubbard, which puts it in a 4 star category for me.

Upon entering the Hubbard St diner I was enveloped by the hometown atmosphere. It seems quite a few locals were here for a family dinner. I say that because I saw three groups hug it out with "hey, how are you? what's been going on? how are the kids?, etc." I came here for the deserts but I know the have great food too. I was torn between the meatloaf, turkey dinner and chicken pot pie. I selected the meatloaf. It was an excellent choose with 2 good sized slabs of meat with mashed potatoes/gravy and a healthy portion of green beans and carrots. A very satisfying meal. I like their cherry pie and ordered that for dessert.   The service was very good, my food arrived quickly and was piping hot ready to eat. I recommend and will return. A classic landmark in Middleton, Wi.
Great place, friendly staff and DELICIOUS FOOD & BAKERY!  I love the fun diner vibe and cute "pie" t-shirts.  Baked goods are dangerously good!  :)   I've been here for dinner a few times!

This place is known for their pies. In addition they are known for their Pie, PI T-Shirts which are awesome!   The location in Middleton, WI, is a perfect little city center. Easy parking next door.   I thoroughly enjoyed my Grilled Cheese, which was pure Wisconsin Cheddar with Lettuce, Tomatos on hearty multigrain bread.  I could barely finish it, but don't worry, no part of the grilled cheese was left behind.  Now, onto dessert.  Blackforest Pie - I wasn't sure how they were going to accomplish this feat, but they did and they did it WELL! YUM!!! The crust was flaky and buttery. Tasty - pie can't be good, unless it has GREAT crust.  Cherry Pie - Delicious crust once again, but the filling, was an excellent balance of jellied cherries that were sweet and tart. - no a la mode needed.  Carrot Cake - most and delicious. Chunks of Walnuts on the outside and pieces throughout the cake - a little too much with the walnuts, but the cake and cream cheese frosting made up for the nuts.  Service was very good. She was neat, polite and prompt. Refills on drinks were never requested, she took care of it before we realized we needed them.  Chocolate Chip Cookie - bought one to go. Had it about 5 hours later and it was still moist and chewy with soft melty chocolate chips - I wish I had bought 12!  I highly recommend visiting for a meal and dessert. Then visit the Mustard Museum next door!!

I went here in 2011, hated it, and thought that after hearing from others how good it was, that it must've been an off-day. After a recent Sunday morning breakfast, I know that they must just be smoking something.  The food here is not good. Don't ask me about the pie, because I didn't have any. I had a benedict-like breakfast sandwich that I couldn't finish (not normal). Heck, I didn't even eat half, and I was effing hungry. The eggs were tasteless, the waitress never refilled our coffee (and we were at the COUNTER, for heaven's sake), and the biscuits were cold.  My guy had a breakfast scramble, which, admittedly, tasted a LOT better than my breakfast sammie, but still, this place sucks for breakfast food. He agreed it was no good and we decided never to come back.   If you have a purse and jackets, get ready to share hooks under the counter, because they're only every third or fourth seat apart. So that can be awkward with strangers. haha  I do NOT understand the long lines to be seated, and I do NOT understand why people come here. If you want the pie so bad, order it for pick up and take it home. It's not worth stomaching crappy food just to earn dessert.

I half expected to see Biff and Marty McFly going at it. The place reminded me of the diner in Back to the Future. Cute, charming diner with a lot of pie options. I should have tried the grasshopper pie. I haven't seen that since the 80s. So many options to choose from. Too bad I didn't.   Small wait, not a biggie. Plenty of pie and dessert to oogle at. Not to mention the pies swirling around the spinning pie display case. Haven't seen one of those in awhile either.  Chicken salad I would have to skip next time. A little too sweet for my liking, but the waffle fries were good. I tend to be picky with the way people prepare chicken salad.  Santa Fe salad was a nice size and was said to be good. Chicken dumpling soup was also said to be good. Cocunut cream pie I guess was okay. Nothing spectacular.  Good service. Charming atmosphere and a lot of dessert options.

The food and the service was overall okay. They took themselves very seriously. I had the quarter chicken dark meat with fries, and it tasted normal but not outstanding. The pie I had was the Mississippi Mud, which I found to be very delicious.   Could benefit from more decor. Overall a nice experience, but I'll try something else next time I'm in town.

Of all the Food Fight places in the area this is my fav!    It's nothing to write home about but it's great for what it is!  it's not your typical diner food, it's got that Madison twist (the tuna gyro, for example) that makes it fun, and more granola friendly!  I've never been disappointed and I Always have leftovers... this may be because I'm always saving room for dessert, which is AMAZING!!    Breakfast is more like a 3.  I have high standards and so far Madison's breakfasts just haven't impressed me yet... it's fine I would just rather make my own, I guess.   The meatloaf is good, the Smokehouse Hickory Burger is great and the fish fry is pretty nice too.  Not a fan of the scalloped potatoes with ham... no matter how many times I try it and want it to be wonderful it dissapoints :(  Service is OK, always nice, usually on top of drinks... they just always seem to be in a rush, which I get on a Friday night, but on a Tuesday when the dining room is not quite full?  Good luck getting any attention if you aren't ordering or they aren't dropping off your food.

First visit to Hubbard Avenue Diner on a busy Saturday morning.  Sat at the counter as it was a 20-25 minute wait for a table.  Service was fast and efficient.  Bloody Mary was good.  Food was average at best.  Too many choices for better breakfast food in the Madison area, not sure I'd give them a second chance.
Great find..   Fresh and tasty ingredients, Breakfast was amazing.  From what i hear the baked goods, pies etc are amazing here and def worth tryiing.  Can't wait t come back

EDIT:  After a few more experiences here, I'm knocking it down to three stars.  The pie is what's keeping it afloat for me.  Good selection and good flavors, but there are a lot of places in town that have superior food.  I haven't been here to eat non-pie food in months.  The Hubbard Avenue Diner was a little difficult for me to nail down.  I've been about five times in the last few months since arriving here.  I landed on four stars.  Cons first:  If I'm at a diner, there's a good chance that I want breakfast, and Hubbard gets dinged for not having breakfast available all the time.  The breakfast food I've had here is good, and I'd love to have it as an option all the time.  And maybe I just caught it on a bad day, but the chicken pot pie I had last visit was really bad.  The menu advertises "a garden" worth of vegetables, and this must have been a very small garden.  Also, the gravy in the pie was extremely watery.    Now for pros:  Good, solid diner food, a tick above usually greasy spoon diner fare.  The location is fantastic.  Parking is always easy.  There's never a wait.  The servers are pretty efficient, if not always super friendly.  The pie alone is worth the price of admission (chocolate walnut is excellent if you're into it).  I find myself wanting to go up here from where I live on the West Side a fair amount, but I never leave as happy as I hope I will.  It's a really good spot, but with a little bit of menu tinkering, it would be even better.

I was shocked I was in a diner! My friend took me here & said it was amazing & probably busy. I said on a Monday afternoon in little Middleton, Wisconsin? You betcha! My friend had a grilled salmon Caesar salad that was quite tasty. I had the NY Reuben with turkey, extra cheese & sauerkraut. Phenomenal! I got extra sauces with waffle fries and I have to say, this is the FIRST time in 20 different restaurant visits that I asked for Ranch dressing and it wasn't watered down! The place was packed on a Monday afternoon, so we ate at the counter. Hubbard's specializes in pies & baked goods. Overall, I was impressed. My sandwich with fries was about $10 and so worth it! I said I 'd be back next time I'm in Wisconsin. The service was prompt & friendly; kudos to the kitchen staff because even though it was a full diner, we received our food in a very timely manner and it was hot! I'm recommending this place to everyone in the Madison area!

The phrase "Good things come to those who wait" comes to mind regarding Hubbard Avenue Diner.  This is a suburban diner that is quite popular. Located in the heart of the 'downtown' of a bedroom community, there is always a wait even mid-afternoon.   I come here strictly for the fried chicken special as I get my fry on the outside and do not cook that way at home. 5/5 on the chicken, veg, and mash! I don't know of a better place to get fried chicken than this. Fresh, hot, crispy.  Dining companions have got a variety of things. Fish, mehh. Burgers, acceptable. We discovered brunch exists on this most recent stop! Quiche comes with two options. The hash brown base was quite thick; we will select the pie base next time. In short, ask questions about preparation, etc. if you are concerned with high satisfaction on your entree.   As you may expect from a place that celebrates the numeral 3.14 with a Pie Day event, and pi t-shirts on the staff, the pies are where its at. Blueberry is my depth on that and its superb. Typically I get cake! They are high! They are mighty! They are classic! They are tasty! I'm a regular for carrot cake.  One star removed because the cookies have been stale 100 percent of the time. I don't know why but 100 percent of the time over several years the cookies are no good. Kids deserve quality items and I think they are getting ripped off along with the parents paying for them!   One star deduction because servers don't make it back after the food has been delivered! Staffing is lighter than it needs to be in this always-packed establishment. Management isn't visible. Perhaps they could check on folks and refill drinks! I can't say I've had friendly service here. People appear too busy to be pleasant.  Rating is not helped by the seating/decor. Go here with companions you enjoying conversation with because there is nothing else in the place to entertain you!  In summary, this is a reliable place for a decent meal when you have plenty of time. They know they are the pie place so dining menu is playing second fiddle. Value the wait time by perusing the pie case. Study the choices for the dessert decision that inevitably awaits!

I don't think I've ever had a meal at Hubbard that I haven't enjoyed. We tend to stop in here on lazy Sundays when we pathetically can't be parted with our pj's because they do a yummy brunch quiche special till 11:30 or 12:00.  I recently had the Huevos Rancheros on one of my better "early" mornings, and it was FANTASTIC. Crunchy corn tortillas, filling black beans, eggs your way, and cheese--because this IS Wisconsin. Good salsa verde with a kick on the side.   I was, however, deeply disappointed in the brownie i had them bag up for me, though. It was dry, and not rich. I didn't even finish it. I DIDN'T FINISH A BROWNIE.  Guess I gotta stick to the pie!

CREME BRULE PIE IS THE BEST DESSERT IN TOWN!!!  This is my new go to brunch place on the west side.   My review is on the overall experience......not a huge menu, but they seem do get each dish right....service can be slow, but they are always packed so that is somehwat expected.  I have gotten the Southwester Eggs Benedict every time we go, and always good. Salsa Verde is as good as mine, and healthier choice than typical hollandaise sauce.    Hashbrowns are really crispy and great flavor (not too greasy).    Was there every Sunday the last month with out of town guests (usually get going around 11am), and do expect a 20ish minute wait, but it's been a blast to visit the mustard museum after putting our name in at the diner.  It's a great way to show guests around town, taste some amazing mustards, and then have a great brunch!    So, I had been waiting to try the creme brule pie when my mom was in town last weekend, but found out they only carry certain pies certain months (in the case).   I was all sad, asked the baker, and voila was able to pick up a mini pie the next day!  OMG, we were just going to have one bite, and then split the rest for later.   We stood at my kitchen counter and ate the ENTIRE mini pie!!!  It was so flipping amazing!!!

I was very happy with my recent visit to the Hubbard Ave. Diner.  The place was surprisingly busy for a weekday evening, but I soon realized why--the food is delicious.  I ordered the beef stew and it was everything I hoped it would be. Luckily I still had room after the beef stew because I also ordered a cappuccino and a pie of Mississippi Mud pie and they were excellent.  The one negative was that it was really hard to decide upon what to get for dessert because all of the cakes, pies, and cupcakes looked wonderful.

I'm giving this place 5 stars based on their peanut butter silk pie alone! I don't even care about what is on their food menu, this pie is worth the hour drive. TAKE ALL MY MONEY! It literally melts in your mouth. Each bite is the perfect combo of sweet and salty. I love that the crust isn't chocolate. And that the topping is real whipped cream. This pie is what dreams are made of.
Perfect diner atmosphere in downtown Middleton. Classic food done well, though nothing extremely exciting. Eat pie and enjoy the charm!

Been there a few times and while I would not write home to mom about it, the breakfast is good if standard and the service is fine.  Coffee house coffee fans may be a bit disappointed, but it is the sort of place where most people can find something decent on the menu without breaking the bank.  The atmosphere is classic American dinner which is pretty nostalgic, but the place, including the bathrooms were clean the few times I ate here.

We stopped here for breakfast on day 2 of our Southern Wisconsin mini vacation. We were waiting for the Mustard Museum to open and Hubbard Ave. Diner is literally right next door.  The breakfast food was ok. Chris had eggs, bacon and pancakes and I had potato pancakes with a side of bacon. It was nothing exciting or memorable, but good enough. It was a bit pricey for what we got.  We loved the Art Deco design and architecture of the place although it is new and not period construction. They have a large assortment of pies on display, though we didn't get a chance to try any.  The service was good and the restrooms were clean and handicapped accessible.

Yes, I am a fan. I love this wonderful mid-century vibe style diner. This is the place that I take friends especially if they are visiting from overseas. Their staff is very friendly and attentive. I love their dessert offers, right when you come in you can see the display of dessert. My favorites are the key lime pie or carrot cake.  Regarding their food, I like their weekly specials and their burger and sandwiches. Last time I went I had their chicken salad croissant sandwich and it was excellent. Make sure to leave room for dessert or one of their fabulous milk shakes.

Great food. Awesome pie. A little too pricey. Wonderful atmosphere.  Fun times. I go as often as I can afford. The prices are the only detractors for me but I have a tight budget. Nice big yummy salads. Crafted soups. Pie from Heaven. Deserts galore! Yummmy. When I was at Little America this summer the engineer that runs the little train told me he goes in there all the time because he loves it there. It made me smile when he said that because we talked about the pie while we were riding the train. That tells you how good the food is because that's a heck of a drive.

Good basic diner food with a decent veggie burger. Otherwise, vegan options are basically nonexistent. It is a shame that they do not have some vegan pies because the non-vegetarians in my family really enjoy them. It is also kind of odd that they are located about a block from a great, vegan-friendly bakery (Blooms), which should provide inspiration.

I've been to Hubbard Avenue Diner a few times, and the food is a mix of average and super-good.   Hits: Smokehouse Hickory Burger (subbing a black bean patty for meat), French Silk* pie. *Most FS pies are light and creamy; theirs is dense and fudgy. I wouldn't personally call it FS, but I will call it heavenly.  (Occasional) Misses: Their regular fries (I'm a potato gal, I've got high standards; on my last visit they were dry and over-cooked), the parmesan penne (bland), and the Italian Turkey BLT (the first time I tried it, it was amazing; the second time it was okay at best - can't put my finger on why).   The diner itself is adorable with a wonderful mid-century vibe, offers outdoor seating when the weather is nice, and has a friendly, attentive staff.   If the rest of their desserts are as good as the French Silk pie, a visit to Hubbard Avenue Diner is worth the visit for a treat alone.

This is one of more established and consistent Food Fight Restaurants in the greater Madison area. They are sort of famous for their pies.   I had beef stew. Companion had pot roast. Of the two I thought the beef stew had a richer flavor. The veggies that came with the pot roast were simply steamed. They would have better if they had been roasted with the pot roast.   Both the pot roast and the beef stew came with mashed potatoes. They were a bit thin for my taste but had decent flavor. Also since they were potatoes in the beef stew, I found the addition of the mashed potatoes with the beef stew to be a redundant filler.   Hubbard Street Diner is provides consist service and decent food - in the end I guess it's what a diner is supposed to do.

We just ordered pie tacos to go. Very very good and easy to eat. It may not be earth shattering once you have it, but it's the novelty that counts. It is a great way to eat pie sans utensils. All of the flavors are great.
Another fantastic Food Fight establishment. Food has always been great for the 15+ years iv been coming. Highly recommend the malts!

Not bad, not great. You'd like it to be a diner with an enormous menu, along the lines of what Ella's Deli has. When it gets crowded, orders take a long time. Not particularly inexpensive. I'd like to see them up their menu, with more variety and better quality, but they've never changed in the last 8 years, so I am not expecting anything.
If my mother was a diner, she would be embodied by Hubbard Ave Diner..this place epitomizes home cooking. It makes me happy, warm, and fuzzy. Thank you Hubbard Ave.

One of the best places hands down! Amazing pie, shakes, food and service. Always prompt service and reasonable prices. Fun atmosphere and whole menu is delicious for any mealtime. Highly, highly recommend!

The reason this restaurant gets two stars instead of one is that our server was an all-star who handled a difficult situation to the best of her considerable ability. Unfortunately, the food did not match her service.  I ordered the soup of the day, which was a sausage vegetable soup. The soup was very oily, and went heavy on the garlic. While it is normal to have a little extra oil in a soup with sausage, this soup had a film of it around the sides and slightly undercooked carrots. It is difficult to get carrots properly soft in a soup, so I'm not dinging them for that, but I would be lying if I said that I wasn't a bit disappointed by the experience.  For my main course, I ordered "Mother Hubbard's Chicken Pot Pie" which should really have been called "Mother Hubbard's Chicken Pot Soup." Chicken pot pie is supposed to be a thick, creamy, and flavorful dish with the consistency of a thick stew. This pot pie was a milky bland broth of the same consistency as my sausage soup, which contained rubbery chicken covered over by a puff pastry. I sent the dish back, which is the first time I have done so in any restaurant.   As a replacement for the pot pie, I ordered the 'Mediterranean Penne.' To Hubbard Ave's credit, they managed to get the dish out quickly, and when the check came it was the only entree they billed me for. To their detriment, the kalamata olives still contained pits, and the feta cheese was disappointing.   To finish off, I ordered cheese cake. It was adequate, but nothing that I'd write home about. If I return, I think I'll stick to the pie.  Review Update:  After my last experience, where the food could be categorized as dreadful, the General Manager, Jose, reached out to me over private message and apologized for the experience my wife and I had. He offered us another trip to the diner, on him, and we accepted. I did not order the Pot Pie this time as, although Jose assured me that he had seen to the error that turned it into a soup last time, I did not have faith in the kitchen's ability to turn the dish around.  This time, my wife and I were accompanied by a friend. We all ordered burgers, and I have to say, the blue cheese and bacon burger worked out a lot better than I thought it would given my last experience with a cheese here. The waffle fries were also excellent. For desert I ordered a slice of French silk pie, which was better than your standard restaurant desert by a pretty wide margin. My one complaint is that the service was a bit slow, even after the rush died down.   This experience was a 4/5, the previous one was a 2/5. Overall, I think it averages out to a bit above a three. Good enough for diner food, and I appreciate the effort their management went to in order to make things right after things were brought to their attention.

The first time I stopped here, was before a night out with my man. I was so hungry, and I still had 15 minutes until my table was ready at another restaurant. I saw that this diner was full with people, and people were even starting to wait outside the restaurant. This is how I knew I had to stop by. We shared a peach scone (DELICIOUS), then headed over to our dinner reservations.  The next weekend, late on a Sunday morning, we decided to go and try out the breakfast at the diner. We arrived at about 10am, and waited about 20 minutes for our table. Not too bad, considering how busy the diner was, and also because there was a full display of pies and other baked treats to look at. I ordered the breakfast quiche, with the buttery pastry crust. My boyfriend ordered the eggs benedict. They were both delicious, and extremely large portions. I previously planned to order a slice of pie to share, since they're known for their pies. But at the end of the meal, I knew I had to save the pie for a different day.   Good, cozy atmosphere. I would recommend coming earlier if possible, but even during its' busy hours, the wait was very tolerable. Good service, good food, what more could you ask for?!

Went for post night-shift breakfast, because we were told we could drink here early in the AM. And we did-- the bloody marys are delicious, and spicy. The french toast is also delicious, not so spicy. All six of us enjoyed the hell out of our food, even though they made us wait out in the cold until they opened at 7.   Overall, a great diner breakfast experience.

The pies are totally overrated. Just because they offer like 100 different pie flavors doesn't mean they do them well. I've tried six different pie flavors from this place, ranging from fruit pies to chocolate pies, and in between. Each time I've just felt a little disappointed, and that the pies look better than they taste. Pies are supposed to be their big hit. Can't speak for anything else on the menu as I've only gone for pie.

I've been here a couple times. My honest assessment is that the food is average, but you come here more for the experience. By which I mean pie, obviously.  I most recently came on a Friday night after practice, at 8pm. The place was packed. I hadn't had dinner so I needed some food. Since it was Friday night, I felt like I had to get some fish fry but i was tempted by the breakfast food. That was a mistake. The fish fry is pretty mediocre. Fish is not crispy, kind of soggy and very soft inside, and essentially unflavored. The breakfast food that some of the rest of the group got looked average, but I mean that's diner food right?  That's all to say that you're coming here for the pie. They've got a pretty good selection, ranging from your fruit pies to cheesecake and silk pies. A slice is the same price for any flavor. Again, I wouldn't really consider any of the pies special - but the bit of chocolate silk I got from someone who couldn't finish her piece (I think it was the chocolate silk part of duo of silks) was not silky (fluffy) but more like a dense, creamy chocolate pie which I like much better than silk anyway!  They've also got a number of pie-related word play shirts and stickers.

Highlights/lowlights  -great service -just like many Madison brunch spots be prepared to wait -good food  Came to Hubbard Avenue Diner on a busy Sunday morning around 11:30. The space resembles a 50's diner, particularly the bar area. We were told there was a 20 minute wait for a table or we could be seated at the bar whenever space was available. Two seats opened up right at the bar as soon as we got there (obviously fate). Sometimes you don't get great service when you sit at the bar, but that is NOT the case here. The service at the bar was excellent. There were a lot of great options on the menu but I finally landed on the southwest omelet and my boyfriend got the "mile high" (Denver) omelet. Both omelets were great and balanced the egg, extras, a cheese really well. We will definitely be back again!

The Hubbard is okay. The food isn't bad, but it's not as outstanding as they think it is. Not is it as good as the price they charge.   Oh, and what they call apple sauce is really pie filling in a cup!
I love the vanilla malts (and they're huge), and our 14-year-old son loves the burgers. It's a fun spot, in the classic diner style, though it's only 10 years old.

Like the true deli experience, the true diner experience is hard to find in these parts. The Food Fight group's twist on this slice of Americana nails it in most respects and misses it in just a few. Here are my key performance indicators for excellence in dinerology: - Simple food spun up by a short-order cook with a mouth that makes a sailor blush.  - Bad coffee brewed in a Bunn-O-Matic and poured by a gruff waitress who, with her smoker's voice and polyester uniform, can keep up the banter with the foul-mouthed cooks.  - Pie for dessert.  Here's my analysis of the KPIs:  - We didn't talk to the busy cooks, but the waitresses appear as if like they could hold their own in the kitchen. They don't wear polyester. That's OK. The food is simple: turkey dinner good, cole slaw good, skip the fish fry, eat the French fries. The patty melt is an old diner standby. Get it here, even if it's Lent and you're Catholic and it's Friday. If God has tried the fish, he'll excuse you.  - The coffee is OK, not terrible, and the pie is great. If you visit during the holiday season, do yourself a favor and get the candy cane pie and ginger cake.

This morning I got up early to join the boys' "breakfast club". It was pretty delicious! I'm a big hash brown fan, and the Morning Scramble special did not disappoint. My only complaint is that the edges of my eggs were slightly cold, and the cheese wasn't melted. But I can look past this, due to the savory browns.   The decor is somewhat 50's, with an odd collection of teapots and a wall painted with the names of all the pie flavors available. I love the plastic coffee thermos they leave on the table for you. Hood Half n Half! Domino Sugar! This spot is pretty authentic and the service was great.  Next time, I'm trying the Breakfast Quesadilla or Daily Double :) But for now, I'm sleeping in...

The breakfast was very disappointing. I have not had any other meals here. However their desserts: cookies and pies are yummy. I don't think i would ever buy a meal here again. However i will stop in for a cookie or 2 ;)

Three and a half stars. This place is a lot like Monty's-- the menu ought to be appealing, but isn't. The food is ok, and the service is a half notch above what you'd expect.  Oh, and yes, the pie is decent. Not amazing, but above average.

Solid old school diner in the heart of Old Middleton. The daily scrambler is always tasty and good size and comes with hash browns and a home made biscuit. I'm not a big fan of hash browns, so I wish they offered american fries as an option. That being said the hash browns are good. The coffee they serve is Colectivo and is a popular choice for people in the Madison area, but I find it a tad too dark & bitter for my liking. Overall Hubbard is a great pick for breakfast and the atmosphere is great and the customer service is stellar.

Waiting time way too long - also you can see available tables.  My omelet was "2.5 out of 5".....dry and not high quality.  Hush Brown was "ok".  ENGLISH muffins remind me the time ISRAEL was escape from Egypt......ston are less hard....  Not my first visit....they do have great pies tho, but we didn't order it this time
don't matter. You need food? They got it, and lots of it! And pies  service is amiable. You pay at the front. There's parking. Writing is difficult. I love pie!

We had dinner here in a group of 4 and it was a pretty good experience. I ordered one of their burgers with fries and, although it wasn't quite as good as some of the burgers from the classic pubs in downtown Madison, it wasn't a bad burger at all. I also order their fresh-squeezed orange juice and it was as fresh and as good as advertised. To be honest though, I was a little underwhelmed with their pies. Maybe it was because they hype them up so much that my expectations going in were too high but I just wasn't blown away by any of the 4 different ones that we ordered. Still, the atmosphere is really nice and the prices and portions are reasonable, so I'd definitely come here again and give a different pie another try.

Went here for my birthday lunch yesterday, suggested by other members of our 4-pack. Collectively, I give Hubbard 3 stars but I'd give my meal 1 star. The corned beef on my Reuben was inedible, I pulled it all off and tried to enjoy what was left of it. I feel like they were getting rid of the leftovers from St. Patrick's day....it was thick, extremely tough, and dry. I attempted to cut it into smaller pieces but even a fork and knife couldn't tear through it. Another member of our party said her one piece was like that but the other was fine. My fries were average, but generous. My husband had the smokehouse burger that he said was amazing, and my grandpa's scalloped potatoes and ham was "just ok".   The service was attentive, but not overly friendly. She did notice my gift and let us know I got a free slice of pie for my birthday =)  We noticed they were on a wait when he left at 12:45p, so this place obviously stays busy.  The restaurant and bathrooms were incredibly clean.   The mint Oreo pie was delicious!
Good spot if you are interested in an updated old style diner. Clean and friendly with a splash of unique foods. Main focus is on the pies which are 5 star.
Love love love!  They have great food all around, great service and  even better pie!  Its a go to joint for me when I visit family in the Madison area.

We stayed at the wonderful Country Inn and Suites in Middleton last weekend and volunteered for the Ironman WI. By the way all five of us girls ate on Monday morning, you would think WE all did the Ironman on Sunday....but we did all sign up for the Ironman 2013 in Madison. I had the BEST  Huevos Rancheros with hash browns. The homemade salsa verde has a definite kick so if you have a timid stomach, you may want to avoid it. Me: I asked for extra salsa. Great service, prompt delivery of our food and healthy portions.   We were all so full we didn't even have time for pie,which was very disappointing. It looked so delicious.  We asked the hotel for a local diner and we loathe Cracker Barrel for reasons I don't think appropriate to voice here.  Bravo Hubbard Avenue Diner!

We visited the Hubbard Avenue Diner for the first time recently. We were looking for a place to go after taking in a movie nearby and after reviewing their menu and website decided to give them a try. The Hubbard Diner has a fairly extensive menu (a few more vegetarian/vegan options would be nice). While they are not bar-oriented, they still had some local crafts on tap and in bottles. My kids went for the Baked Mac & Cheese which they devoured. I had the black bean burger and fries. Which was good. Appeared to be a homemade patty (not pre-packaged). Our server was nice enough, but not overly friendly. Some of the other staff seemed a bit grumpy the night we were there (which was a Saturday around 8PM). They were out of several of their pies--including their key lime (which we probably would have sampled). The place itself seemed a bit worn, but nothing that would deter me from stopping again. Hoping for smiles and pie the next time we visit.

Hickory Smokehouse Burger - Excellent! I also had the Yellow cake with strawberry filling and butter cream frosting.  It looked like a Strawberry Shortcake....  It definitely looked better than it tasted.  It was dry and didn't have much flavor. The Vegetable beef stew was good. My biggest caveat...  No breakfast all day.  What kind of diner doesn't serve breakfast all day?  Breakfast is a huge moneymaker.  Sell it all day.

I was lucky a couple of weeks ago to get to visit the Hubbard Avenue Diner. I have heard so many good things about it so I was excited to finally get to visit for myself. First off it is just fun to eat there. It has a wonderful classic diner feel to it. I had a burger that was very tasty. We received great service from a very friendly waiter. I will be back for sure!

Sunday pot roast dinner.  Please, go on a Sunday.  Be overwhelmed.  It's just amazing roast beef (pull apart tender) with a giant helping of mashed and gravy along with a dinner roll and beans and carrots.  Our waitress was one of the nicest, most genuine servers I've ever had.  Ever.  She bounced from tables to the counter and always stopped to ask how we were doing, if we needed anything, and give us some tips on dining and sights around the area.  The pie.  Oh, the pie.  I had the duo of silks.  Out of this world good.  I highly recommend this place over Bluephie's (same restaurant group, different take at each place).

This is another example of a restaurant that survives and thrives based more on reputation and perception, than actual food quality. When one claims to be a diner, the fundamentals of such a claim should start with breakfast. Frankly, how hard is it to screw up breakfast? You don't have to make an outstanding breakfast, but you have to make one that at least is as good as one would make in their own kitchen. Such is not the case with Hubbard Diner. If you read the reviews by Scott C and Hannah M, you will note that they are intrigued by the uniforms and t-shirts, rather than the food. If I want to go somewhere to see great uniforms, I would think of the Wynn in Vegas or the Borgata in Atlantic City. I came here for the diner food.  The scrambled eggs were dry and brown. The hash brown was bland and again, dry. The toast had a nice flavor but was hard and cold. The orange juice was not fresh squeezed but rather tasted like what McDonald's serves. How do you get away with serving this type of breakfast and still able to call yourself a diner? The decor is cute and kitschy. The use of the math symbol for pi is fun but not unique. All of that can't overcome the plain, and rather bland food.  I would like to thank the patrons who dined around me that morning for making me realize I am still in back-ass dumb-f*ck America. Despite the fact that less than a mile away is a Starbucks and other chain restaurants, rural america still exists. The table across from me was a group of gentlemen discussing electricity and wiring on a farm, while the table behind me had two older men talking about Jews, how cheap they are and how they go to their own temples to worship whatever they worship with their own people. Thanks fellow patrons for making me remember why I prefer urban centers and I am always much safer in Newark or Harlem than I ever will be in back-ass, farm lands.

I came back just to have a piece of pie but this time around dinner time the place was packed with the line out the door. I asked if this was a busy night because of the graduation weekend but was told this was a slow night, oh boy. Most of the pie case was emptied out so there were slim pickings to choose from. I lucked out and got a fudge bottom pie with Bavarian cream on top to get my fix. I ordered it to go and at it in the lobby at a high top. I wish they would have offered that option instead of trying to figure it out on my own. Love the pie but not willing to wait in the crazy line for it.

I had a positively delicious breakfast on a Sunday early afternoon.  I got the breakfast quesadilla stuffed with scrambled eggs, black beans, and not enough cheese. It also comes with a side of homemade salsa that was super pureed and did not have enough heat or chunks of tomato for my liking.  Seriously though, despite these two things it was still quite tasty.  The place was packed but our service was excellent.  The pies/cakes looked amazing, must try!
Carrot cake is Devine! The best I've ever  had!

I would take my parents here if they visited Wisconsin.  It's a cool old timey atmosphere with a spot-on quiche.  The selection of desserts and pastries this overwhelming for your eyes. However, I tried the Cherry Rhubarb pie, and I must say that my stomach was rather underwhelmed. I was prepared to be blown away, but I found the pie lackluster. The crust was soggy, and there was no pizazz to the filling. Even the ice cream was bland (not their fault).  To be fair, I tried one pie, but I wouldn't want to be disappointed by another one. I'm sure I'll try Hubbard again in the future, but it won't be anytime soon.

Generally tasty, nicer-than-typical diner food. There are better places in town for breakfast, but they cover the bases. For lunch and dinner, the NY Turkey Reuban and the chipotle chicken salad are two of my favorites.  I have never really cared for their pie crust, though the duo of silks pie is really good, and the mint brownie way surpasses the regular brownie.   Can get pretty busy during peak meal times, but the wait is never too-too long.

UPDATE! I have finally tried the food here. I got one of the chicken wraps with a small cup of chili, and the bf got the chicken and chips. Both dishes were well prepared and really hit the spot. The service was quick and attentive, and our food came out fast. I especially liked the fried chicken, it had the perfect amount of crunch and the chicken was surprisingly moist.   Great spot for comfort food!

So I've only been once, but I can't see ever coming back. After a pretty ho-hum lunch I decided to get a slice of cherry pie to give the diner a chance at redemption. It was a chance they squandered.  Very average all the way around.
Just a point of clarification -- the Old Fashioned pie was flavored like the cocktail and they did a bang up job of it!

My husband and I went to Wisconsin regarding business.  On our way back home I decided I wanted to try apple pie somewhere there since I saw so many fresh apple trees in the area...I thought...the pies must be good here.  We asked a local restaurant we had lunch at for their recommendation and they recommended Hubbard Avenue Diner.  We were immediately greeted by Sam , he was friendly and extremely helpful in suggesting a few options.  I ordered the apple pie, which I originally came for ...crumbled apple pie that is...and my husband decided to go with an option of Sams.  Although not bad, the pie Sam recommended wasn't to my husband's liking...but Sam immediately replaced it with one my husband chose this time...well..the second one..my husband wasn't a fan of either..again..nothing wrong with the pie..i actually liked the second one ...but just wasn't what my husband was looking for...we didn't want to have Sam replace a second pie...but Sam came over to make sure we liked the pies we were tasting...and we let him know it wasn't what my husband was looking for but it was ok, not to worry about it..but Sam insisted to give us another one ..so i finally told my husband to go for the crumbled apple pie...which I was having...Sam packed one for us to go. He didn't have to care so much that we like the pie..but he did...he found it important that we drove all the way there to try their famous pie and that we left happy..and because of Sam..and that awesome crumbled pie...we definitely left very happy....i kind of wish i had gotten a large pie so i could be sitting here eating another slice now.  I highly recommend you order the crumbled apple pie and get it warm.  btw...they are very lucky to have an employee like Sam.  We own businesses and we know the importance of having an employee that exhibits such great customer service.

I came here on a Saturday for brunch and Hubbard Avenue Diner did not disappoint! We arrived around 1pm...the place was busy, but they seem to turn over tables fairly quickly. We only waited about 10 minutes to be seated. I LOVE all the pi references =)   We ordered coffee and the waitress brought a small carafe to the table for self-serve refills. Nice! For food, I ordered one of the daily brunch specials, an egg scramble with sausage, mushrooms, onions, and cheese served with hash browns and a biscuit. The scramble was cooked well and included the right balance of eggs and "stuff." Hash browns were crispy and the biscuit was flaky and delicious. My breakfast mate ordered the daily quiche, which included a unique hash brown crust (rather than a pastry crust). I was told it was yummy =)   Overall, I'd come back to Hubbard for a solid, quality brunch. The breakfast menu is not super extensive, but they offer good options, plus the daily specials keep it interesting. I'd like to try some of the more unique dishes, such as Potato-Zucchini Pancakes or Breakfast Quesadilla.

FOUR AND A HALF STARS! When we first walked in for breakfast, we were amazed by the huge, delicious pies that this place is famous for making. We were seated immediately and our friendly waitress was very quick to deliver our food! Great portions, great prices, great atmosphere! I definitely recommend this for anyone who wants an authentic diner experience!
A gem in Middleton Wisconsin.  The only place I want to go for breakfast on a Sunday morning, along with every other resident in the town!  Good food with a quality staff.

Food's good, but a bit pricey. $3.89 for a side of bacon, which consisted of three scrawny pieces is hardly worth it when you consider a whole pound costs a little more. Biscuits are good. Light and flluffy. Southwestern Eggs Benedict are delicious. Definitely will be back but never ordering side of bacon again

I called ahead to order the new item:  Pie Tacos.  I placed an order for two dozen.  The flavors were Apple, Cherry, French Silk, and Key Lime.  I got there 30 minutes earlier than I said and the order was not yet put together.   I was fine with that.  It did take a while to get the order together and it was very messy.  I think carrying out a smaller number would stay nicer.  The fruit pies kept their shape the best in transit.  The cream pies with the whipped topping fared far worse.  The tastes of each pie were good...as reported to me by everyone who dug into the box of treats.  I personally sampled the Key Lime and French Silk.  The Key Lime had a soggy "taco shell" so it was hard to pick up.  The flavor was spot on but I wished for a spoon.  The French Silk's shell kept it's integrity but the whipped topping was easy to lose.  It has a good chocolate taste.  The box with the cream pies was a whipped cream mess.  I ordered these on the first day they were available.  So with that in mind, the packaging is forgiven as it was an experiment.  I am sure this will get improved in the future.  And the pies all tasted very good and are fun.  I would order the pie tacos again but would be more inclined to eat them in the restaurant or carry out only one or two for the road.

I went with colleagues and I had the meat loaf and mashed potatoes with gravy and salad. Meat loaf was tender and the food was pipping hot. The diner roll was excellent too! It was so good I didn't get a picture.

Just a great dinner!   If you're looking for a old fashion dinner this is the place. Great breakfast and great lunch.   If you want breakfast on the weekend come early or plan on waiting.  Loved their omelette!!! My wife got the eggs Benedict. We can't wait to go back. They have a huge selection of pies and we haven't even tried the, yet. Next time we'll save room.
Had Mac and Cheese with chicken and was completely satisfied, awesome pie and great service!

Have not eaten here in years. Remember the food was good, but the service was terrible. Tonight we arrived just as they got really busy. Ordered the steak kabob at the server's suggestion. The veggies, sauce, and rice were really good. The meat was over cooked, dry, and inedible. My companion had the grilled cheese sandwich which was absolutely delicious-- the bread was grainy and wonderful, it was filled with melty fantastic cheese. Her fresh fruit was also good. The chocolate shake was great.   Service has improved dramatically- except that the server didn't ask how I wanted my meat and didn't check back with us until we were finished. She was very apologetic and gave us complimentary pie to make it alright. Not a bad experience, but not the greatest. I'll try again another time.

YES desserts!  Rest of food...be wary of what you order.  Hubbard diner and Monty's Blue Plate are like opposite sides of the spectrum--Hubbard celebrates being retro, Monty's says "Yeah, we have a vegan version of that!"  A lot of the menu items are the same, but somehow, Hubbard's versions usually suffer.  I once ordered the quiche and found it nearly inedible.  The quiche was like a dense scrambled egg pie.  If I ordered food again, I would stick with 1950s American classics like burgers, grilled cheeses, and tuna melts.  The desserts at Hubbard are fabulous.  Every pie option, from fruit pies to cream pies, are absolutely delicious. I recommend the Caramel Apple and the Duo of Silks. The Hot Fudge Brownie is insane...I thought it would be more like brownie a la mode but really it's like hot fudge brownie for 3 people.  And delicious.  I have also accompanied a friend for a wedding cake tasting here, and all the cakes we sampled were fabulous.   I'll happily stop by for dessert any time, but am hesistant to return for a meal. Get a slice of pie and sit down at the counter!

Absolutely love this place! Breakfast lunch and dinner menus have such eclectic food choices, I truly believe there is something for everyone. And that doesn't even include DESSERT! The most important meal of the day! And Hubbard Avenue definitely puts their sweets in the limelight. My personal fav: Lemon Meringue. My kids LOVE the cookies! My husband loves the Chocolate silk pie!

Great place.  First time here....the atmosphere is a diner with a 1950s type vibe inside and out.  Son said the pancakes were awesome but are heavy.    I had the Mile High omelet.  You can taste the fresh veggies that were in its  They are known for their pies and I hear they are AMAZING. Food is good and not easy...service is good too.

Finally got a chance to visit this place! I heard about it first because of their famous pies. They have so many flavors and also season flavors that change. Was so hard to decide, but all of them were good.  I also chose to dine in. The meals are very tasty and in large portions.

I visited friend who recently moved to Middleton this weekend. She hasn't had the opportunity to fully explores that many places yet, so we took the advice of the gal at the Kinko's counter and had brunch at Hubbard Avenue Diner.  I always feel so much better about a place after I find a decent place to enjoy a meal...I think it's my favorite thing about traveling. Hubbard Avenue Diner provided an extremely comfortable environment to have conversation over coffee, get a decent meal, and have a piece of pie if you're so inclined.  Coffee was great. Breakfast cooked to perfection! Fresh biscuits, carnivore omelette was amazing with meat that tasted better than usual, hash browns weren't greasy like those those had after bar at Denny's the night before. Gross!  I will definitely make a return visit to Middleton and will definitely add brunch at Hubbard Ave Diner to my itinerary.

As always great service and food. Staff is friendly and they really know their pie! I think I ate too much but there can't really be such a thing as "too much pie" especially at this place. Every pie I've ever had here has been nothing short of orgasmic. The food is great too and the restaurant is in the heart of Middleton with ample parking and much to do nearby like the national mustard museum and the Middleton library. The price is a bit higher but there you're paying for location. I always make a point to stop here whenever I'm in town.

It's a Food Fight restaurant, and this place has reliably decent food in big portions for reasonable prices.  It's very similar to Market Street Diner in Sun Prairie, and like there, the real star of the show is the pie.  I've only been here for dinner, and I've never had any complaints.

I think this place has a lot of potential, but for whatever reason just can't seem to get it together.  I'd heard only good things about it, by foody locals, so I thought I would be at least satisfied if not impressed. However, I left with an overwhelming felling of "meh."  I'll give them another shot, but it won't be anytime soon. Maybe I'll buy one of their many pies next time? There's got to be some reason they stay afloat, right?

I think I need to visit again, as I was slightly underwhelmed with my meal. I got the turkey with mashed potatoes, gravy and mixed veg. And a side of coleslaw, because I'm a sucker for coleslaw.  It really was average at best. The turkey was kind of dry, the mashed seemed instant, the gravy was good. The veg were meh. Bland and watery. The dinner roll was decent. The flavor was good. The coleslaw was too sloppy. Lots of mayo, but still fairly bland.  It's completely possible that I should visit again and try something from the breakfast menu. Or pie. My choice may not have been the best out of what they have to offer, so I will be back to try something new. And pie.

Great food, clean restaurant and restrooms. Absolutely packed, about a 20 minute wait but very nice waiting area. The meatloaf dinner was great but it could have used a larger portion of mashed potatoes. I like a good meat to potato ratio. There was a generous serving of vegetables and a roll, overall a really yummy meal. Will definitely return!

Every time we go to Hubbard I really want it to be good but it's just OK at best. The atmosphere is suppose to be American diner-ish. We like to sit at the counter if we come for breakfast to avoid a wait. The pie is good but expensive. Service is OK, better at the counter then seated. The scrambled eggs are always a little overcooked and a pretty small portion. Same with the bacon overly cooked, slightly burnt, really small puny, pieces. I do like that they serve classic hash browns. And the pancakes are good. But overall breakfast is not as good as it should be for them pushing the "classic diner" theme. I think I've been once for lunch or dinner but not memorable and I remember our son's burger was way overcooked. Prices are comparable to other places or slightly more expensive, maybe because of the area they are in.  Its a nice place if you live in the neighborhood but we head to the Original pancake house or Monty's for stellar breakfast food for the similar prices, larger quantities and better quality.

I love this neighborhood diner, and it's not even my neighborhood.  Be sure to follow the diner on Facebook for specials. Today was free pie if you wear your Hubbard Diner T-shirt...YES!  My hubby and I grabbed two seats at the counter just before Noon. All counter seats filled up soon thereafter.  We each had a bowl of one of the soups of the day: Chicken Dumpling. It was delicious and so full of plump hunks of chicken, my hubby was like "did you get any dumplings?" Yes. I did.  Then the real hero of our lunch: pie. He had double crust cherry, and I tried Creme Brulee. Both were delicious!

Always our go to for breakfast!  All other meals are wonderful too.  I order pie first with my coffee and then eggs to follow.  I have never been disappointed.  Other suggestion besides their outstanding pie:  biscuits, fried chicken, pot roast, and scalloped potatoes with ham

This was my first time to Hubbard's, and I wanted to find out if this diner was living up to some of the reviews.    The vibe was cute and and had a fun atmosphere, and the hostess was organized.   After about a ten minute wait, we were seated.   The menu was what I expected for a diner which was breakfast, sandwiches, and traditional family dinners like a hot Turkey plate.    I knew coming here that their specialty was the desserts and I mean the pies, however, pies is not my thing. I ordered the two egg whites scrambled, bacon, and pancakes.   It was average and nothing exciting.   The others at the table ordered the Reuben and the vote was it was just ok.  I would have thought they would of had a killer Rueben since most diners do.   Oh well.   The service was good but did not give me a memorable experience.    Overall, it was a good try but with all the other options it didn't leave me wanting to go back.

We arrived around 10 and it was very busy. We did get a table after about 25-30 minutes so not too bad. We ordered our drinks and then our waitress had a medical emergency. We ended up waiting for about 30 more minutes before finally placing our order. The food was good and service was excellent after the wait. They did take care of us very well even though issues popped up that were out of their control. I would definitely go back.

Amazing place for breakfast, brunch, or lunch!  Great variety of food options for the entire family.  The food is a little priced, but the service you receive there is well worth it.  Everyone is always so willing to serve you, whether or not they are assigned to your table.  In addition to the food, the location really makes for a great experience.  After your meal, it's nice to walk around downtown Middleton looking at the different shops.

I don't get out to Middleton often enough to know the caliber of its restaurants.  My vague impression is that it's a bunch of middle end chain places (Macaroni Grill and the like).  Therefore, Hubbard gets extra points for at least being locally owned in a town of chains.  Menu is mostly comfort food staples.  Lots of different pasta bowls and sandwiches. Highlight is the  Meatloaf of the Gods.  However, like most Food Fight establishments, Hubbard is merely OK.  Big on presentation.  Lacking a bit in the really tasty food category.

Very tasty comfort foods. I love their chicken chili and their milkshakes/malts. I had a great experience with the brunch on Christmas eve morning.  We have also ordered cakes here and they are always beautiful and tasty. They are very very slow.
Went last with with the wife (who is vegetarian), I ordered a classic burger and she ordered a portobello burger. We both were impressed. Pie was good for desert. Service was good. Overall recommend!

This terrific little downtown gem was just the spot to fill us up after a visit to the local brewery. Their homemade vegetable soup was flavored with dill and quite good. The star of our lunchtime was the ham and potato casserole smothered in delicious Wisconsin cheese. Savory and melty and gooey and wonderful. But.... also too good to pass up was their pie. We shared the cherry-rhubarb and were glad we tried it. Rhubarb - a first for us Phoenicians, but very tasty. I'd eat a little less lunch next time just so I could have more pie. Great service too - thanks a bunch!!

Great place to eat for good diner food. The fresh toast is especially good and the coffee is never ending....gotta love that. Great bakery case as well...pies galore!  Parking is ample, staff is friendly and if you get there around 7:45 on a Sunday morning seating is instant.  So, if in Middleton looking for a place to eat...that should be your choice.

I would rate Hubbard about a half a notch above "typical" diner food. I came for lunch on a weekday and was able to get a seat right away. My waitress was very prompt, though not overly friendly. I ordered the veggie bean burger, and though it was perfectly acceptable, it was not fantastic. I also ordered a slice of the apple pie and I must say I have tasted better. To me, the filling tasted like it came straight out of a can. Nonetheless, the menu is extensive and is sure the have something for everyone, and the bakery case is quite the eye-catcher to all who walk in the front door.

Loved the breakfast so much we went here two days in a row!  Pancakes and French toast were both awesome, as were the hashbrowns (cooked just how I like), biscuits, and veggi benedict.  Wish I would have had a chance to try the pies because they looked great too!  The service was very good both times.

Great little place!  The menu is pretty diverse and I always enjoy my meal.  SAVE ROOM FOR PIE for dessert!  You MUST try a slice of something!  Their pie selection is insane!  A MUST stop for breakfast or lunch if you're ever in Middleton!

This diner in downtown Middleton was close to the hotel we were staying at. It was about a 10 min wait on a Monday evening.  I had the catfish sandwich with a chili side. The catfish sandwich was dry and the chili side was cold. My coworker had the pulled pork sandwich in which she described the buns as "brick-line!"  My second co-worker had the catfish bowl with cornbread which was just okay.  For dessert we had the boston creme pie which was very disappointing.  I had the strawberry rhubarb pie which was probably the highlight of the night. I heard that the lemon white chocolate pie was only good because the flavors were different.  Maybe it was just a bad night but I'd recommend to skip this diner and try somewhere else.
